Award.AwardTitle: Educating Advanced Driver Assistance Systems Technicians
Award.AbstractNarration:
The most dramatic shift in recent transportation technology has been the development of autonomous vehicles and intelligent cars. The Bosch group estimates that more than half of all cars first registered in 2017 came with at least one advanced driver assistance system (ADAS). Examples include rear collision warnings, parking assist, emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, blind spot monitoring, and lane keeping assist. The deployment of ADAS in vehicles is expected to continue to grow over the next 10 years. This project aims to produce workforce-ready ADAS technicians for the automotive industry by adding instruction on ADAS systems and diagnosis to the Collegeâ€™s automotive technology associate degree program and developing an ADAS technician certificate. This project, backed by industry and academia, will be designed to educate graduates who are skilled in ADAS methodologies and, thus, fill a gap in the modern automotive workforce. As a result, it will contribute to the national need for a highly capable advanced technological workforce.

This project intends to improve student learning in science and engineering technician education by: 1) developing up-to-date ADAS-intelligent vehicle course content; 2) implementing an ADAS technical certificate program tied to a relevant industry credential that was developed in partnership with national automotive credentialing organizations; 3) acquiring autonomous vehicle simulation and ADAS lab training equipment; and 4) obtaining hands-on ADAS vehicle diagnostic trainers and autonomous vehicle mini-labs. These curricular improvements and new equipment will enable students to learn fundamentals of ADAS systems and diagnosis including sensor technology such as Light Imaging, Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), wireless systems, radar units, ultrasonic transmitters, and steering angle sensors, as well as to use the same equipment that they will use in industry settings, including ADAS camera alignment fixtures with scan tools. Project impact and success will be evaluated through performance-based techniques, using a mixed methods quasi-experimental design to analyze qualitative and quantitative data about project components. This information will be used for ongoing project improvement. Materials and learning objects developed by the project will be disseminated via the Center for Automotive Technology, the North Florida Transportation Planning Organization, the Florida College System, Advanced Technological Education Central, and other channels. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Educating Advanced Driver Assistance Technicians project aimed to create curriculum to address the educational needs of those who may work with Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) and Connected Vehicle technology. As the automotive industry adds new technology, it is important to equip the workforce. This requires training of both current and future technicians. Additionally, recognizing that educators play a pivotal role in this process, it is crucial to equip them with the new technology. This ATE project worked to create curriculum to train STEM educators, both current and future technicians, and also reached toward educating secondary students with the new ADAS technology. This comprehensive approach not only prepared technicians but also inspired the next generation, ensuring a skilled workforce was ready to meet the demands of an increasingly tech-driven automotive industry.

Project objectives included 1) developing and creating course curriculum for use in an Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) technical certificate; 2) establishing ADAS and Autonomous Vehicle simulation and lab training equipment for students to practice applying skills; 3) obtaining hands-on ADAS and intelligent vehicle trainers and sensor mini-labs to provide underrepresented populations challenging applied science, engineering, and technology curricula and professional development for post-secondary education and K-12 faculty and staff.

The project relied on industry experts to form a Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) committee that directed the curriculum development. With the help of the BILT committee, two new courses on the new ADAS technology were created and five existing automotive courses were modified to create a new technical certificate in Advanced Driver Assistance Systems.  

Newly created courses:

  • Advanced Drivers Assistance Systems and Diagnosis
  • The Connected Car: Autonomous Systems and Diagnosis

The project was able to purchase three vehicles with ADAS technology along with an ADAS calibration frame and tablets which enabled the students to perform calibrations accurately.

The project initiated the development of an ADAS educational trainer that demonstrated live RaDAR, LiDAR, Camera systems, Ultrasonics, and Yaw Rate sensors. Additionally, the project created a portable Connected Vehicle demonstration area that uses a traffic signal controller and signals that communicate with vehicles and a CV2X antenna. With this demonstrator students can see a working CV2X system to understand the technology in a live CV2X system.

The project hosted multiple career exploration events with hundreds of high school students to explore ADAS technology and career ladders for employment with ADAS technology. These events focused on career pathway awareness and strengthening mathematics and science skills for underrepresented groups. Female students represented the lowest population in the automotive student population. With efforts of recruiting and marketing, the project increased the female population enrollments from 6.3% to 25.7% over a four-year period.

For three years, FSCJ hosted multi-day summer boot camps for both middle and high school students to introduce the topic of obstacle detection through a hands-on robotic building "boot camp" and live vehicle demonstrations.

The project created an educational pathway that connected secondary students to post-secondary education. An automotive dual enrollment structure was completed for secondary students to attend the Florida State College at Jacksonville (FSCJ) automotive program and begin training in ADAS technology.

The project successfully delivered ADAS automotive curriculum in which forty students enrolled in the new technical certificate. There were thirty-two STEM and automotive secondary teachers trained in ADAS theory and calibration. All teachers were supplied lab kits to demonstrate ADAS calibrations in their classrooms. The project was able to significantly improve underrepresented group enrollments. The equipment that was purchased allowed for successful training of college students, secondary students, STEM teachers, and incumbent workers across the ethnic spectrum. The outcome of the entire project is clearly preparing current technicians and also inspiring the next generation to meet the demand of an increasingly tech-driven automotive industry.
